questions: What is the function of ComfyUI-NDI?
How can I use NDI video stream frames as input for ComfyUI?
Can I use a web camera as an input source for my NDI model?
What python version was used to install ndi-python with ComfyUI-windows-portable?
How do I add an NDI receive image node in ComfyUI?
What should I do if I cannot find my NDI resources in the ComfyUI node?
How can I view the real-time output of the model using ComfyUI-NDI?
answers: ComfyUI-NDI is a real-time input output node that allows you to access NDI video stream frames and send images generated by the model to NDI video streams.
To use NDI video stream frames as input for ComfyUI, you can capture your web camera or screen of a painting software like PS as input.
Yes, you can use a web camera as an input source for your NDI model by using the `Screen Capture` from NDI tools.

To install ComfyUI-NDI, download the repository, unpack into the `custom_nodes` folder in the ComfyUI installation directory, clone via GIT, or install `ndi-python` using the command `pip install ndi-python`.
The python version used to install ndi-python with ComfyUI-windows-portable is `3.10.9`.
To add an NDI receive image node in ComfyUI, right-click on the NDI group and find options for receiving and sending images.
If you cannot find your NDI resources in the ComfyUI node, click the `update ndi list` button in the menu.

To view the real-time output of the model using ComfyUI-NDI, add an NDI send image node and connect it to the image output. Then, you can view an NDI resource named 'ComfyUI' using a software called 'Studio Monitor' from NDI tools.
